title: SAS troops almost blown up after ISIS booby-trap dead children's bodies
text:

British special forces were almost blown up when Islamic State fighters booby-trapped children’s dead bodies with hidden grenades.

The small SAS convoy was heading to the Iraqi border in north-eastern Syria when they spotted two children lying by the road and thought they may be alive.

The elite troops stopped to help and set up security positions in case of an ambush.

Four of the group approached the children – believed to be brother and sister, aged around five and eight years – carrying medical bags.

After inspecting them, they realised they were dead and found 14 deadly grenades beneath them.

(Image: Getty)

Wires were attached to the grenades’ pins, taped to the corpses and buried in the ground.

Any attempt to move the children would have tugged on the wires, removing the grenades’ pins, and cause a massive blast, killing those who came to their aid.

Fearing there could also be mines or roadside bombs planted nearby, the team searched the road for explosives and then spent an hour dismantling the grenade necklace which had been laid under the kids.

The soldiers dug a grave at the side of the road, buried them and paid their respects marking the spot with a series of stones.

A source said : “They were heading towards Iraq when we saw the kids, you see lots of bodies but kids are different and we thought they might be alive and couldn’t just drive past.

“They know IS used bodies to hide IEDs and carefully checked to see if they were alive, quickly spotting more than a dozen grenades hooked up to them - sadly they were both dead.

“It is thought they were brother and sister. They couldn’t leave them lying there, so cleared the threat, buried them together and said a quick payer, it wasn’t much but they could in difficult circumstances.”

Despite IS’s defeat in Syria there are thousands of Islamic State extremists still at large in sleeper cells bent on revenge.

(Image: Anadolu Agency via Getty Images)

The heavily- armed SAS patrol had been operating in north east Syria with other special forces units when it was ordered to withdraw to the Iraq border following the decision by the Turks to mount an offensive against the Kurds.

President Trump’s sudden move to pull out 1,000 American special forces troops paved the way for the Turkish invasion which has threatened genocide against Kurds.

Yesterday Russian troops, who along with Syrian regime forces, have come to the rescue of Kurdish troops in “deal with the devil” rescue pact, continued their advance towards Turkish lines.

But Turkish president Recep Tayyip Erdogan has defied pressure for a ceasefire in Syria and said the only way the offensive would end was if Syrian Kurdish fighters leave a designated border area.

Russia said it was working to prevent a conflict between Turkish troops and Syrian government forces that have moved into Kurdish-held areas in the northeast.

The American move effectively abandoned the Kurdish fighters who were allied with the US and cleared the way for Turkey’s invasion aimed at crushing them.

In an address to his ruling party legislators, Erdogan said Turkey would not be coerced into stopping its offensive.

He vowed to press ahead with the incursion until Turkish troops reach a depth of 18-20 miles inside Syria along a border area where Turkey intends to form a “safe zone”.

(Image: AFP via Getty Images)

He brands YPG Kurdish forces inside Syria - who make up the western-backed YPG - as terrorists with little distinction between them and the Kurdish PKK terror group.

The approach has attracted widespread condemnation since the YPG/ SDF have not operated inside Turkey.

It is suspected Erdogan is terrified the Kurds’ successful state of Rojava would encourage 14 million Kurds inside Turkey also to pursue an independence.

Mr Erdogan ruled out direct or indirect talks with the Kurdish fighters, saying Turkey will not negotiate with “terrorists.”

He added: ““We are not looking for a peace mediator nor do we need one.”

Yesterday Turkish forces and Kurdish fighters were still battling heavily on Wednesday over the border town of Ras al-Ayn.

Turkey captured the town days ago, but its hold now appeared uncertain after the Kurds fought back.
description: The small SAS convoy noticed 14 hidden grenades when they stopped to check on two kids lying by the road in north-eastern Syria
